awd_titl_txt: Study on Effects of Flame Retardants on Chemically-Inhibited Diffusion Flames
awd_abstract_narration:
High-performance and low-cost brominated compounds are popular flame retardants but are being phased out due to environmental and health concerns. It is urgently needed to find environmentally friendly alternatives. In this project, research will be conducted to investigate the effects of various compounds on chemical inhibition in diffusion flames that bear resemblance to real fires. Measurements of flame structure, with corresponding numerical simulations, will shed light on the interactions of flames, flows, and inhibitors. This project will provide the basic understanding of the detailed chemical inhibition mechanisms of potential flame retardants, including both halogen-based and halogen-free compounds. The resulting knowledge will help develop proper screening and testing methods for characterizing flame retardants.  This project will benefit society by promoting fire safety and reducing fire losses.

This project is to study the effects of gas-phase chemical inhibitors on the structure of coflow diffusion flames, generated using a cup burner. The goal is to obtain a better understanding of flame extinguishment and retardation mechanisms. This work will be focused on the gas phase process, thereby excluding condensed phase charring phenomena. The research team will investigate, experimentally and computationally, the structure of methane and propane diffusion flames with halogenated and halogen-free (phosphorus) inhibitors added to the air or fuel. Unlike premixed flames, the transport of inhibitors and active intermediates play an important role. Modern combustion diagnostic tools will be used, including particle imaging velocimetry, thin-filament pyrometry, and planar laser-induced fluorescence of OH and CH radicals. The experimental results, including flame structures and minimum extinguishing concentrations of inhibitors, will be compared with the transient axisymmetric computations using full chemistry and multi-species transport. This work will greatly advance our knowledge of the combustion and inhibition behaviors of the selected halon replacement agents and phosphorus-containing retardants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Fire safety relies primarily on passive and active fire protection, i.e., more specifically, materials flammability and fire suppression, through preventing ignition, reducing flame spread, and extinguishing fires. These processes can be achieved by removing or reducing one or more element(s) of fire tetrahedron, i.e., fuel, oxygen, heat, and chemical chain reaction. Flame retardants are used to reduce the flammability and flame spread of various solid materials such as woods, polymers, textiles, and their coatings. Fire-extinguishing agents are used to suppress fires occurring in air environment. Flame retardants or fire suppressants containing halogen atoms (bromine, chlorine, and fluorene) are highly effective to remove radical species (especially H atoms and OH radicals) and thereby inhibit the chemical chain reaction required in fuel decomposition and oxidation processes.

 Brominated flame retardants are one of the largest marketed groups due to their high performance efficiency and low cost, but some toxic compounds have already been removed from the market due to environmental and health concerns. Chemical systems of highest interest to flame-retardant industry are halogen-free compounds. An effective fire-extinguishing agent Halon 1301 (CF3Br) has been banned from production by the Montreal Protocol due to its destruction of stratospheric ozone. Unfortunately, certain alternative halogenated hydrocarbon fire suppressants have been found to produce enhanced burning and hence they fail the Minimum Performance Standard of the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration. Nonetheless, to maintain fire safety, alternatives to these compounds must be developed.

 In this project, the gas-phase interactions of an inhibitor (retardant/suppressant) and the structure of diffusion flames have been investigated experimentally and computationally to gain better understanding of flame retardation and extinguishment mechanisms. Two types of laminar coflow diffusion flame burners, in which a gaseous fuel issues from a circular tube in a coflowing air inside a concentric chimney, with vastly different fuel-tube inner diameters (26 mm and 0.4 mm, respectively) are used. The former is an industry-standard cup-burner, in which the fuel velocity is exceptionally low (< 1 cm/s), and the latter is a high-speed fuel-jet burner (up to 20 m/s), compared to the air flow (up to 40 cm/s). The cup-burner flames bear some resemblance to real fires due to the low fuel momentum.

 First, to determine the efficacy of inhibitors, the minimum extinguishing concentration (MEC) was determined in the cup-burner diffusion flame by adding each inhibitor to the surrounding air stream until extinction. The fuel used was methane or propane. The inhibitor was CO2, N2 (chemically passive), C6F12O (Novec 1230), C3H2F3Br (2-BTP), or their blends (chemically active). Secondly, the flame structure was investigated in the cup-burner flames with a particular focus on the flame base region, including the flame-attachment point and a trailing diffusion flame. The combustion diagnostic techniques used include the particle imaging velocimetry, the thin-filament pyrometry, and the thermocouple measurement.

 Furthermore, the stability mechanism of laminar coflow jet diffusion flames was studied using the fuel-jet burner with n-butane fuel, the heaviest alkane in a gaseous state at ambient temperature and pressure, having the reaction mechanism similar to that of higher (liquid) hydrocarbons. The critical mean n-butane jet and coflowing air velocities at flame stability limits were measured using small fuel tube burners.

 Finally, time-dependent numerical simulations were performed with full chemistry and multi-species transport to reveal the detailed flame structure of both the cup-burner and fuel-jet coflow diffusion flames. The experimental results provided rigorous testing of numerical models, which include comprehensive descriptions of combustion and inhibition chemistries, radiation heat losses, and multi-species transport. A peak reactivity spot (i.e., reaction kernel ), possessing the hybrid nature of diffusion-premixed flame structure, was formed at the flame base and controlled the flame stability. The local Damkoehler number, newly defined as a ratio of the square root of the local heat-release rate and the local velocity at the reaction kernel, decreased gradually with an increase in the inhibitor concentration or the air velocity, and dropped abruptly at flame lift-off from the burner rim, leading to extinguishment.

 This research has advanced our knowledge on chemical inhibition and flame extinguishment processes in coflow diffusion flames required to develop proper screening and standard test methods representing the relevant full-scale fire behavior. The flame structure measurements have shed light on gas-phase flame-flow-inhibitor interactions, helped in reducing uncertainties in the reaction mechanisms, and enhanced predictive power for selected replacement compounds. This research will benefit to society and, more specifically, will contribute to the passive and active fire protection, by providing the technical base for reducing fire losses in the nation.


Last Modified: 01/29/2023
Modified by: Fumiaki Takahashi
